properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warm weather continues. This warm airmass will persist over southern Quebec today. Daytime highs are expected to reach between 29 and 31 degrees Celsius with humidex values in the mid thirties. Cooler temperatures are forecast for the end of the week. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-29T06:59:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-28T15:00:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2541844825.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 5:28 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-05-29T00:51:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-28T21:28:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0533090387.2020
Area: Murdochville area, Forillon National Park - Gaspé area, Percé area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Unseasonably warm temperatures and high humidity expected today and Friday Time span: today and potentially into Friday. Maximum temperatures: Temperatures reaching or exceeding 30 degrees Celsius today. Temperatures Friday reaching 28 degrees C. Locations: Southern New Brunswick (cooler temperatures for coastal communities). Remarks: Temperatures are expected to reach or exceed 30 degrees today and 28 degrees on Friday. Humidex values are expected to reach 31 to 37. A cold front will bring a return to seasonable temperatures for the start of the weekend. Heat warnings have been issued for portions of northern and central New Brunswick. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-29T05:59:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-28T14:00:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1249353903.2020
Area: Grand Lake and Queens County, Sussex - Kennebecasis Valley and Kings County, St. Stephen and Northern Charlotte County, Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain possible today. An area of rain moving northward from Ohio this morning will cross lake Erie and western sections of Lake Ontario through the middle of the day. There is the potential for rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 millimetres to fall across some areas by this evening. This rain is associated with the remnants of tropical depression Bertha and is weakening as it moves northward. There is still uncertainty about which area will receive the highest amount of rain however rainfall warnings may be issued this morning. This statement will be updated through today. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-29T00:49:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-28T08:50:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2799127630.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 5:32 p.m. ADT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. Maximum wind gusts: 90 to 110 km/h in thunderstorms. Locations: areas west of Kedgwick and Saint-Jean-baptiste-de-Restigouche. Time span: until 7:00 PM. Remarks: A cluster of thunderstorms between Mount Connacher and Brodericks Hill is moving northeastward at 30 km/h. Torrential downpours, hail and strong wind gusts are associated with these thunderstorms. ### Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing large hail and torrential rain. Scattered thunderstorms have developed across the area. These thunderstorms will be very slow moving. As a result the main threat from these thunderstorms will be heavy rainfall with a slight chance of nickel size hail. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2020-05-29T08:00:16-00:00

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog is expected to redevelop this evening along the north shoreline of Lake Superior. Fog will persist throughout the night but is expected to gradually dissipate late Friday morning as a drier northerly flow enters the region. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very warm and humid weather is expected. Time span: this evening, tonight, and continue Friday in some areas Locations: central and northern New Brunswick. Minimum temperature tonight: 18 to 20 degrees C Maximum temperature Friday: 30 degrees C (Humidex 35 to 38) Remarks: Warm temperatures will continue tonight and Friday. Overnight temperatures tonight are expected to be 18 C to 20 C. Friday temperatures are expected to range from 28 to 30 C over much of the province. Temperatures will be cooler Saturday as a trough tracks across the province. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-29T11:23:34-00:00
